issue.title: R2DBC driver initialisation
issue.body:
I'm going to try out the R2DBC driver and I have a question. With the JDBC driver I could just call `asJdbcDriver` from a data source.

What should I do for the R2DBC driver? Should I instantiate a new Database object every time I'm gonna use it in order to fetch a connection from the data source? How could I use with the connection factory from the postgres driver for example?

_Originally posted by @augustocdias in https://github.com/cashapp/sqldelight/discussions/4761_

issue.title: R2DBC driver initialisation
issue.body:
I'm going to try out the R2DBC driver and I have a question. With the JDBC driver I could just call `asJdbcDriver` from a data source.

What should I do for the R2DBC driver? Should I instantiate a new Database object every time I'm gonna use it in order to fetch a connection from the data source? How could I use with the connection factory from the postgres driver for example?

_Originally posted by @augustocdias in https://github.com/cashapp/sqldelight/discussions/4761_

issue.title: Crash when adding the plugin dependency to JVM application
Crash when adding the plugin dependency to JVM application

comment.body:
I get the same* 

If I remove the `fatjar` 🍯 it does load the build
"from(configurations.runtimeClasspath.get()"

🕊️ I believe that it's because there is a clash between the `fatjar` task reading the `runtimeclasspath` and the SqlDelight plugin adding to it https://github.com/cashapp/sqldelight/blob/27f789cd3a36f8741ee412aa89bd4592514da9da/sqldelight-gradle-plugin/src/main/kotlin/app/cash/sqldelight/gradle/SqlDelightPlugin.kt#L89-L98

Not sure what the solution is maybe changing when the `fatjar` task in run

*with this toml
```
[versions]
version = "1.0.0"

[libraries]
kotlinx-datetime = "org.jetbrains.kotlinx:kotlinx-datetime:0.4.1"
ktor-client-core = "io.ktor:ktor-client-core:2.3.5"
ktor-client-cio = "io.ktor:ktor-client-cio:2.3.5"
ktor-client-contentnegotiation = "io.ktor:ktor-client-content-negotiation-jvm:2.3.5"
ktor-client-serialization = "io.ktor:ktor-client-serialization-jvm:2.3.5"
ktor-client-logging = "io.ktor:ktor-client-logging:2.3.5"
logback = "ch.qos.logback:logback-classic:1.4.11"
jsoup = "org.jsoup:jsoup:1.16.2"
kotlin-test-junit = "org.jetbrains.kotlin:kotlin-test-junit:1.9.0"

[plugins]
kotlin-jvm = "org.jetbrains.kotlin.jvm:1.9.0"
kotlin-serialization = "org.jetbrains.kotlin.plugin.serialization:1.9.0"
sqldelight = "app.cash.sqldelight:2.0.0"
```

Hi, I am Kotlin Gradle plugin developer, and currently working on support of JS and Wasm part in Gradle plugin.
I can add some piece of information why this code is useful in cases of wasm using.

When webpack making bundle, it process dynamic imports to separate files, to before webpack work, you can't know how many files webpack is going to create. It is bad for Karma, it wants to know exactly how many files it should serve for testing.
And karma-webpack plugin makes a bit hacky solution, it tells webpack to pack all modules (async and non-async) to one big bundle. It works well for Karma, but there is problem with sourcemaps in this case! For Kotlin source maps are crucially important, so we initially disabled this behaviour for Karma via `webpack.optimization`, we did it in Kotlin/JS because we have a small count of async modules there, and this combination of settings worked well.
But with wasm, where there are a lot of async modules, it stopped to work. That's why this workaround can be redundant in wasm cases.

But.. I can see another workaround here with webpack `output`. So theoretically it means that Karma has to see all files which webpack has emitted, so you need either workaround with `webpack.output` or with `webpack.optimization. Theoreticlly you don't need both.

But of course I can be wrong here, maybe you have some specific use case which I don't know about.

auto_merge.commit_message:
* Update kotlin monorepo

* Use 1.9.0

* Update plugin ksp to v1.9.0-1.0.11

* Kotlin 1.9 revisits K/N api

* Use deprecated Kotlin/JS target because MPP with single target isn't officially supported: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/KT-52664

issue.title: verifySqlDelightMigration hangs
issue.body:
### SQLDelight Version

2.0.0

### Application Operating System

Android

### Describe the Bug

When executing the `verifySqlDelightMigration` tasks it seems to run forever. Yesterday I had it actually running in the background it and was going for almost 5 hours. Just today I noticed this too:

```
Calculating task graph as no configuration cache is available for tasks: verifySqlDelightMigration
<-------------> 0% EXECUTING [5m 52s]
> :database:verifyCommonMainQueryWrapperMigration
```

My initial guess is that it's somehow a Gradle regression from a previous update that I did. I can also reliably reproduce this; what would be the best way to find out what is exactly is causing this?

I'm using Gradle 8.4

### Stacktrace

_No response_

issue.title: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError in SqlDelightFileType.kt:23
issue.body:
## Error in SQL Delight IntelliJ Plugin

**java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError** in **SqlDelightFileType.kt:23**
Could not initialize class app.cash.sqldelight.core.lang.SqlDelightFileType

[View on Bugsnag](https://app.bugsnag.com/square-inc/sql-delight-intellij-plugin/errors/65397661df891c0008077de7?event_id=6539766100c72c6470420000&i=gh&m=ci)

## Stacktrace

    FileIndexingNotification.kt:47 - app.cash.sqldelight.intellij.notifications.FileIndexingNotification.createNotificationPanel
    FileIndexingNotification.kt:43 - app.cash.sqldelight.intellij.notifications.FileIndexingNotification.collectNotificationData$lambda$0

[View full stacktrace](https://app.bugsnag.com/square-inc/sql-delight-intellij-plugin/errors/65397661df891c0008077de7?event_id=6539766100c72c6470420000&i=gh&m=ci)

*Created automatically via Bugsnag*

comment.body: If it helps, this appears to be just an iOS problem, at least for me. I can run my Android app, and my shared library `testReleaseUnitTest` target, but I can't run the iOS app or `iosSimulatorArm64Test` because of the missing `stately-common` dependency. The gradle task `':shared:compileKotlinIosSimulatorArm64'.` is what's failing in my KMM project unless I explicitly add the `stately-common` dependency.

comment.body: It seems like something has to be pulling in the reference to `stately-common`. The issue is that all stately modules in 1.x.x depended on `stately-common`, but most of common moved to what is now a reduced module `stately-strict`. There is still a `stately-common` but it's in the deprecated/legacy folder. If something references stately 1.x.x libraries, it says you also need `stately-common`, but if something else uses stately 2.x, Gradle prefers that, and those modules don't depend on `stately-common`. So, in summary, I'll dig through sqldelight again to make sure, but it's also possible that another library depends on stately 1.x.x and is causing the same issue. In any case, adding `stately-common` explicitly will "fix" it, but I would also like to nudge libraries using stately to update or remove it over time. It really existed for the old memory model, and still does a handful of other things that will likely be done by other libraries down the road.
